snippet: Teachers remember Ms. Malik, who was born in Pakistan but spent most of her life in Saudi Arabia, as a polite and driven student. But the timing and circumstances of her shift into militancy remain a mystery.
abstract: Interviews with teachers, relatives and neighbors of Tashfeen Malik from her time spent studying at Bahauddin Zakariya University in Pakistan reveal polite, driven student who was also very devout; Malik was in many ways symbolic of conservative influence Saudi Arabia has had on other Islamic countries like Pakistan, as Malik, though Pakistani, was brought up in Jidda.

byline.contributor: Salman Masood and Taha Siddiqui contributed reporting from Islamabad, Pakistan, and Waqar Gillani from Lahore, Pakistan.

lead_paragraph: Teachers remember Ms. Malik, who was born in Pakistan but spent most of her life in Saudi Arabia, as a polite and driven student. But the timing and circumstances of her shift into militancy remain a mystery.

headline.main: Tashfeen Malik Was a ‘Saudi Girl’ Who Stood Out at a Pakistani University
headline.print_headline: In Conservative Pakistani City, a ‘Saudi Girl’ Who Stood Out

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
